column11: Review Text

column8: Great trip on winding mangrove paths
column11: Super trip yesterday in an indescribably beautiful lagoon landscape with rare birds and monkeys who have also come to us briefly. Great mangrove water trails. The tour guide was super nice. We were there about 16:00 and experienced a great sunset. Highly recommended üëçüëçüí™üí™

We went with Muthurajawela Visitor Centre- our local friend booked it for us. There were 9 of us altogether, so we had a boat to ourselves. Everyone enjoyed the tour! We left around 8am on a Sunday, and cruising along the canals was such a pleasant experience. Then we were out onto the Negombo Lagoon, which is so big after the canal! We saw lots of birds- including a kite dive down and scoop up a fish on the lagoon. We saw monkeys, some of which were swimming across the canal as we slowly approached. We saw quite a few monitors sunning themselves on the bank. The whole trip was very enjoyable, and one of our friends booked a second trip to take students on. Definitely recommended.

column8: Great place to visit and take a boat ride
column11: A lovely relaxing boat ride packed with interesting wildlife. The tour guide was knowledgeable, friendly and extremely helpful when we needed help arranging transport back to Nehombo!
A wonderful experience during which we saw birds, monkey, crocodiles and fish during a well conducted and gentle tour of the marsh. Our boatman was helpful and in no hurry. An excellent tour.

We were staying in Negombo We rang the visitor centre first to check there was a boat trip available at a time to suit us, then got tuk tuk It was an excellent 2 hr trip along the canal and then into the lagoon The guide and boat  driver ensured we saw a huge variety of birds, monitor lizards and monkeys We learnt about the way of life of the fishing community Highly recommended

column8: Safe and relaxing tour for family
column11: Safe and relaxing tour. We went at 7:30am so there weren't as many birds to spot but the ride was safe and relaxing for pregnant me and my 93yr old grandmother and my two kids. The boatsman was very kind and polite and willing. Loved it overall.

Fun boat trip through the Negombo lagoon. We ate fruit on a mini island flooded with tide. Feed the rest of the fruit to the monkeys that live in the mangroves. They also really like bananas. Saw another resting iguana. All in all a nice trip of about 1.5 hours. Count on 15-20 euros per person. Although I think there's still some haggling to be done.

The ride we hired lasted approximately 1 hour and cost us $35. First we went under a bridge, and saw many fishing boats docked. When passing near the fish markets, the smell is unbearable and difficult to get rid of. The water in the lagoon is not very clean, there are all kinds of things floating, but they took us to a place to walk on the water that was quite clear. Afterwards they took us to a small island covered in mangroves to see monkeys that jumped into the boat to collect their cookies. Returning to the point of origin we sailed seeing some pelicans, herons, ibis and cormorants. The ride would have been more pleasant if the boat made less noise and less smell of fuel.

Early morning start  7am -  30 minute tuk tuk from Negombo -well worth it to catch the wildlife . Very well informed guide and boatman - who were happy to point out all the birds and reptiles on show and give us a history of the area. 2 Hour trip - plenty of opportunities for plenty of photos and a coconut break half way.
You can hire a boat to take you around on a boat ride. You see alot of birds and simply enjoy the natural nature of this place.

Very disappointing visit to this mangrove. The photos put forward to promote the site do not at all reflect the two hours of visits. You can make a photo say a lot. It is very often dirty and full of trash. A real tourist trap. So I don't recommend.

Our guide arranged a 2 hour boat trip with the visitor centre. What an experience.  You don't have to be an expert to enjoy this. It is a stunning landscape with plenty to see. We even saw a swimming monkey!

Nice start to Sri Lanka trip Arranged from the hotel for 30 euros per person including transport and city trip afterwards We ate fresh fruit in the middle of the swamp and gave the rest to the monkeys For bird watchers it is so because the trip follows a certain mandatory route We did see water birds and a beautiful Smyrna kingfisher Trip lasted over an hour

We spent two days in Negumbo and wanted to tour the protected Muthurajawela Marsh area, which is great for birdwatching. The best time for that is in the morning but we couldn‚Äôt make it, so we opted for later in the afternoon. It was a great experience. The day was quite got, so being out on the water was refreshing. The mangroves are an amazing tangle of vegetation - that alone is worth a visit. And in spite of the late hour, we got to see kingfishers, herons, kites, eagles, cormorants, pelicans‚Ä¶ and countless other birds. And, of course, monkeys and even a young monitor lizard sunning itself on a tree trunk! The boat got us as close as possible (the area is shallow) so we could get a better look without actually scaring the animals. And interesting birds were pointed out to us. It was an excellent experience and we‚Äôd do it again, given a chance.

We arrived in Colombo and stayed at the beautiful Wallawwa hotel near by. Our hotel helped us arrange a boat tour on the Muthurajawela Marsh. We'd read a lot of reviews about this marsh before coming and being a huge lover of seeing animals and photographing them. I definitely wanted to go. We were in Sri Lanka last week of November and so pre tourist season and all the boat operators we'd contacted hadn't opened for the season yet. Our hotel called Praneeth Perera of Muthurajawela by Boat (0774333501  shiranp81@gmail.com) and he was excited and willing to have tourists. Sri Lanka have been hit hard by Covid like many other places but the people are desperate to welcome people back and were delighted to show us around. Praneeth got his boat out and took us on a tour of the marshes. It was beautiful. We didn't arrive until the afternoon so missed the best time of the day to see birds. We saw plenty but apparently early mornings is the prime time. Regardless, we loved it. Praneeth was lovely, his English excellent and he showed us a book afterwards where he teaches himself 4 or 5 new English words a day (blimey they were advanced) all so he can interact better with tourists. Really committed and good knowledge or birds and the marsh. Would recommend! If I'm lucky enough to come back to Sir Lanka again one day I'll do this again, next time in the early morning and I'll use Praneet again next time too. Top tip: Dose yourself in mosquito spray, we were eaten alive on the marshes. Never seen swarms of mosquitos like it. Once the boat gets going you're fine but when it starts and stops there's swarms.

If you go to Negombo you have to check out Muthurajawela Marsh. We were sad because it was our last day but the fantastic tour through the magic canals by the most incredibly educated and friendly tour guide lady on which we saw beautiful birds, water monitors and even an aligator completely blew our minds.

We hired a boat from Diksan Boat Tours and went for 1-hour tour. Diksan is a real hawk-eye and he showed us a lot of pretty local birds. The only thing that spoils the overal nice experience is a huge landfill site located right at the river bank - it attracts lots of birds indeed, however not the kind you would like to see travelling to such exotic location.

We hired a boat for Rs. 3600 at the Visitor Center manned by locals in the area. The ride was through the Hamilton Canal - built by the British in 1804, to the lagoon and then along the mangroves. Aruna was very informative and showed us all the wildlife and educated us on the importance of the wetland and its history. The migratory birds are here until end April but we didn't see many. We saw many birds, water monitors and various plants. A lovely 2hrs spent at Muthurajawela.

march is located in the southern region of the Negombo lagoon in Sri Lanka. Muthurajawela harbors over 194 species of flora distributed over seven major vegetation types which includes marsh, lactic flora, shrub land, reed, swamp, grasslands, stream bank and mangrove forest. Birds are the dominant group of vertebrates in Muthurajawela. It consists of 102 species including one endemic. The mixture of vegetation types and aquatic habitats in Muthurajawela has made it an ideal eco-zone for a variety of birds. In the wetland eco-system Herons, Egrets, Cormorants, Teal, Waders and Kingfishers are found here. This is also a very important breeding habitat of many aquatic bird

This area is the canal and wetlands where you can take a boat trip to spot wildlife. We had a morning trip from a company called Muthurajawela Visitor Centre, which was excellent. You ride on a small boat with a guide who has a keen eye and will spot the birds and other wildlife you travel initially along the canal and then out into the lagoon and wetlands. We were out for nearly two hours and saw lots of wonderful birds, monitor lizards, monkeys, a small crocodile and even jellyfish. It's a great morning out and very relaxing.

Spent an amazing morning on a canal tour.  We felt like we were on the African Queen or the Jungle Cruise at Disneyland.  Lots of wildlife, birds and vegetation.  The canal water was very clean and the knowledge of our guide enhanced our experience.  My husband said it was his favourite tour and it was so nice to be out of the city.

We came here with a guide we had met in Negombo (Lucky‚Äôs Tours) and it was great. This was our first birding trip in Sri Lanka and we saw 30+ species. Local  guide in boat was good but spoke little English and trip would not have been half as good without our guide, Lucky. If you are interested in birds this is a great trip and it‚Äôs also nice if you want a couple of hours floating down a canal/ lagoon. Much better if you go early in the morning!
Peaceful day without any tourists. 1000 R from Negombo with the Tuktuk to the visitor center. Unfortunately it started raining and we had to come back earlier

My husband and I took the boat tour organised by the marsh visitor centre. The guides are incredibly knowledgable and fantastic at spotting animals. it did rain but that didn't spoil the experience at all. We saw several different species of birds, water monitors, and monkeys. Highly recommended and so much better than other river safaris that can be a bit of scam!
Hi, Their is  availability of natural birds watching water canal park. Safety boat ride availability one & Half  hours  very attractive . The early morning time the best to visit this place.

We were worried we would see birds in rainy, over cast conditions but we had a worthwhile, interesting time, good explanations by our guide. Spotted 3 different kingfisher types, 3 kinds of Herons, Egrets,  Cormorants, water monitors, jumping fish.... well worthwhile!

We went with a local man who did not speak English.  It was fun to see the village along the waterways "waking up", and the 40 minute ride was very peaceful.  We only saw a few birds and were surprised there were not more (we went early in the morning).  Perhaps too much human activitiy around this area

We had a 2 hour boat trip with a great guide - the wild life was good with plenty of different birds and we got to see a few monitor lizards.  The best thing for me was seeing the pelicans on a tiny island and the fisherman‚Äôs changing their nets.

We have just had a very relaxing boat trip from Muthurajawela visitor centre for 90 minutes costing 13000slr each. We went along the canal and into the lagoon. We saw lots of birds including King fishers and herons and passed fishermen catching prawns in the lagoon. The visitor centre consists of a few posters so the main reason for going would bethe boat trip

We took an early morning trip through the Dutch canal and wetlands with an experienced guide to assist and finding wildlife along the way kingfishers, egrets and herons as well as a juvenile crocodile and many water monitors. This trip is a must see for sure.

Our Hotel Covanro organised a driver who brought us to the Muthurajawela Bird Sanctuary on our second day in Sri Lanka. We really enjoyed the slow boat trip down the Dutch Canal,  into the Negombo Lagoon & the trip around the lagoon islands bird & wildlife spotting. Our boat man pointed out various birds & animals & gave us ample time to get our best photos. It was not busy, just our driver & us on the boat. We were on the boat for about two hours. We visited on a Sunday morning. Very relaxing & interesting introduction to beautiful Sri Lanka
We had  90 minutes boat ride in the marsh.This is a good trip for tourists.We were not able to see many birds though.The mangroves provide beautiful view.

We arrived at the visitor's  centre around 8am by Uber and were a little worried when the driver drove away.  To say the visitors centre is underwhelming would be an understatement.  The display of faded photos was very dated and without a booking the guy at 'reception' looked as though a coach load was about to arrive... any minute.  We saw nobody all morning and had the boat and guide to ourselves (surprising as, I read later, it was national wetlands day!).  Having said that the trip on the boat was great.  We saw lots of different species of birds, water monitor, baby crocodiles.  The boat took us along the canal, through the lagoon and mangrove.  I loved it.  Great to see such a beautiful area so close to a big city.  Much underrated area of natural beauty.  The government should plough lots of money into such valuable areas and update the signage and visitors centre posthaste!

Booked this prior to our arrival and had good communication from the local team, opted for an early start (7am) on the advice of other reviewers. I was glad that I had done this as the tranquillity of the marsh was a great way to start the day. This is a small outfit, just a driver and a guide taking you out on a boat to look at the local scenery. We didn't see anything here that we couldn't see elsewhere in Sri Lanka but it was a good introduction to the birds and wildlife in the area, I didn't think that I would like birdwatching so interesting. Please do not arrange this through your hotel or local operator, it is easy and much cheaper to get yourself in a tuk tuk and arrange directly. I can understand why the other reviewers thought that this was expensive but ¬£7 for a 2hr trip was ok by me.

After reading other reviews we chose the 9 am start and paid R1300 each ( there were 4 of us ); Our guide gave us some interesting information before we left and explained about fishing methods and showed us some of the traps they used. We saw a large water monitor nearly straight away and the saw another 2 on the journey. The driver was very good and would stop and manouver the boat so we could get come good photos. We saw the purple heron and different types of kingfisher, bee eaters, got a great photo of cormarant with a fish it had just caught. Also saw fish eagle. Our guide was good and we enjoyed the trip

Well, having read the reviews here, I decided to give it a try.  No one answer the phone and their web doesnt exist and so I had to take a cab and go to the "Visitors center". They charged me LKR 5000, e.i. more that 35 USD for 90 min tour through a man made canal to the lagoon, around a couple of mikro islands and back. We saw literally 12 birds, baby croc, pelicans sitting on a tree ... by coincidence /really?/ we saw exactly what other visitors have seen here. If it was a tour for ten bucks, ok...but 35 :(... Absolutely NOT worth the money!

The Muthurajawela sanctuary is a birders paradise. There is opportunity to see many endemics as well as migrants. The location can be easily accessible from Colombo and Negombo. Most hotels can arrange transportation or you can arrange an Uber ride. You should reach there early by 7am to be in the first boat. This will give you an added advantage. Many water birds and other passerines can be observed as well as some Raptors. The ride will take you on the historic Dutch canal upto the Negombo Lagoon and it is quite interesting for nature lovers. The boats are covered and will give some protection against the sun once it comes up. You can call the visitor center and pre book the ride. Details can be found on Google maps.

...we chose the wrong time to go. We were advised that last trip was at 3pm - trips were leaving as we returned nearer 4:40pm. This is important as during the heat of the day, many birds and other animals are hiding from the heat. Early morning trips offer the best viewing. However, although we didn't see many birds, we did see quite a few - kites, bee-eaters, kingfishers, egrets, pelicans, lessor cormorants, and quite a few other that I can't remember the names of, in addition to monitor lizards and a baby croc! So, I would have given a higher mark if we had gone later/far earlier, which is not really fair on the park - I'm sure it would be better then and get a higher mark. The tour was well guided by the local Marsh ranger/guide and she was very informative and knowledgable.

Muthurajawela is a biodiversity hot spot in Sri Lanka. There was a another wetland belongs to Muthrajawela few years ago which now separated due to Katunayaka highway. Habitat of Mangroves surrounded by this wetlands mainly disturbed due to new construction but it's majestic beauty still visible . There are boat tours from Negombo and other areas if you want to visit.

We came straight from the airport on our first day in Sri Lanka. We were a little early for our booked boat trip, but only had a short time to wait. We set off slowly along the canal on a little boat and right from the start both the driver of the boat and the guide were pointing out birds of a variety of species. We made our way out into the lagoon at the end of the canal  and continued along various other canals. We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves, saw lots of birds and some lizards, took loads of photos and were ready for a sleep while our driver drove us northwards.

I didn't know about this place before I go there. When I stay at a hotel in Uswetakeiyawa my guide and driver Mr Mihiraj suggested me to do that. We started 8 am from the hotel 1. first we visited Negombo fish market. 2. We visited whole Negombo for 4 hours including Negombo fort, Eththukala the hotel area, a beach with catamarans, few churches and we drove through beach road to Muthurajawela starting point. I was not hungry and we didn't eat a proper lunch. On the way to Muthurajawela Mihiraj suggested to by some fruits. So we bought some fruits ( A pineapple, guava, water melon and few bananas) We had a picnic lunch at the starting point of Muthurajawela and visited their small museum too. The cruise was nice and I like the starting too. About 3 km we sailed through the Hamilton canal. Both sides of the canal very green and also filled with brackish water. Then we arrived to the famous Negombo lagoon.  After sailing through the lagoon we came to the wet land sanctuary called Muthurajawela. At the sanctuary we were able to see many birds, few small crocodiles and some brown monkeys. I enjoyed this visit a lot thanking to Mihiraj. I can recommend Mr Mihiraj as their Driver or guide or transporter for foreign visitors who willing to visit Sri Lanka. I'll write his contact details as a help for future visitors. his email - mihirasuriya@gmail.com my tour with him almost one month now. His charges for transport very reasonable too. He's very careful, knowledgeable and good driver too. As a lady solo traveler I'm totally satisfied with him because of his good care. The fee for Muthurajawela visit was very reasonable and it's really a different and nice experience.   The staff of Muthurajawela community center also very friendly and knowledgeable. Thanks everybody

It must be mentioned the people who do these trips are generally volunteers and paid very little for their efforts. They are all without exception enthusiastic and knowledgeable. The boat drivers are usually fishermen and the guides know their birds as animals. I recommend the mornings as a better time for a trip. Remember also that the amount of bird life varies with the seasons, but there is always something to see.

We (family of 5) paid a tour operator R8000 for the trip - 2 tuk tuk each way at 10am from Rani Beach and boat with skipper to guide us round. Seemed a bit dodgy as we weren‚Äôt sure that the drivers would still be there to bring us back - but they were and we had a really great trip - first through the fishing port which was fascinating, and then around the lagoon, stopping to step out into a couple of the islands and to see the monkey colony. Overall 1.5 hours on the water. It was low tide and we grounded more than once and couldn‚Äôt get close onto the monkey beach as a result. Tip: Check tide times maybe ? All in all a great trip and worth the money

I'm not sure where it all comes from, via the sea to the North of the lagoon, or more locally, but it shamed me to experience it. The lagoon was beautiful and could be again. We were alongside a group of Chinese visitors feeding monkeys on Kakkaduwa Conservation forest (!!!) Where a local guide amused them by throwing a plastic water bottle for the monkeys to open. The lid was discarded and we didn't wait to see if the bottle was recovered. The monkey's looked depressed, and so was I having witnessed this. I know I'm just another "middle class tourist", but this was the worst I've seen during 6 weeks in Asia and it made my jaded heart sink a little further. Somebody please take care of this beautiful location and restore it to what it should be.

Thanks to earlier reviewers I booked directly with the Visitors Centre for a 3pm boat ride of 1.5 hours duration for 1300Rp each. We actually pretested the route by tuk tuk in the morning as I have been having language issues with the guy opposite the resort. The fact he thought I wanted a pharmacy when I tried to pronounce Muthurajawela probably says a lot about other tourists! It appears when travelling south from Negombo that the tuk tuk goes the long way round but we were told at the centre that the route indicated on google maps is now impassable. I note also that the price seems to have increased since May. However at Rp2600 fir two plus Rp2500 for the tuk tuk for 3 hours or so (must stay for the return) it was a lot cheaper than the Rp9000 each being quoted by the hotel. (Presumably get there by aircon car, but the boats are all the same on this route). The  visitors centre contains some quaint background information, reminiscent of a primary school project. There is a restaurant there but it was closed both morning and afternoon. Take correct money, change was nearly a problem. Pee before you get aboard. The trip itself is along the old Dutch canal for about 30 mins, where water monitors, various kingfishers and moorhens abound, plus the odd local trying to handcatch fish in the water. Then into the lagoon proper, and finally into the maze of what are a form of mangrove here. All very pretty and definitely a surprise after the pollution and noise of the mainland. Plenty of birdlife including great grey herons, cormorants, shags, egrets, kites, sea eagles and what looked like an owl. We didn‚Äôt see any monkeys or baby crocodiles. I was sceptical about crocodiles, but have since read they do inhabit lagoons throughout SriLanka. Might think twice now about kite boarding on the lagoon! Would probably book the 7.30 am trip next time. I suspect you can just turn up - each boat seats eight passengers and I never saw any with more than 4 people, two passengers, one driver and one guide. Yes a pleasant way to spend a late afternoon, followed by cocktails at sunset.

We booked a 4pm slot and took a tuk tuk at the rate of 1800 including waiting (we gave him 2000 as he was a sweetie). Seeing in the visitors centre the wildlife on offer, I was disappointed as Id seen many of the fauna before, but the reality was far from disappointed. The canal offered large water monitors and some birds, rhe open lagoon was spectacular but my favourite was the mangroves along the river. We saw many different birds  , Macaques. The flora is interested tooand our guide was very knowledgeable and ee had a laugh. Gave the guude and driver 700 to share making the whole glrious trip ¬£12.50 per head. A bargain.

Booked via Viator: all well arranged but if I read other prices in the comments here,  we paid too much.  About the visit: it started with our first Tuk Tuk ride ever from the hotel to the marsh: tha was a nice experience and the 2 drivers were very  nice people. Upon our request  we had also a not planned short  stop at the fish market and a cemetary. at the Marsh we found that our guide knew al the animal names in Dutch, which was easy for us.   of course it is a pre-programmed tour so they know exactly where to look, but we got some real nice pictures of dozens of birds , monkeys and  the water monitor. so:  a good trip, but compare some prices for this tour.

Driver took me here at 6:45 for a pre-booked tour. I would recommend a later time. You can have your own boat or a crowd. You will travel down the canal to the lagoon. Along the way you will see birds , I saw 16 different kinds and water monitors, lizards, and jumping fish. The museum is little more than faded posters. There is a nice little toilet you can use before your boat ride.

We paid R8000 for four people which included our tuk tuk from Rani beach resort (north of Negombo). Tuk tuk journey was 45/50 minutes each way. Guide was knowledgeable about birds but not especially knowledgeable about ecology ( or perhaps there was a language barrier?). Spent a while on a canal before getting into the lagoon proper. This tour is different to the canal tour (in Negombo) offered for a third of the price.
I think it's enough of having 3 hours trip to cover us .Mostly you can see local and foreign birds ,Crocodiles,Iguanas ,Mangrove trees .But different Eco system.

After reading the TA reviews we caught a tuk tuk from Negombo direct to the Visitor Centre - a 45min drive & got our driver to wait for us & take us back - 3000 rupees return. (Isolated out there & no tuk tucks in sight) Booked our 3pm tour by phone with the Visitor Centre in the morning. We were the only 2 on the boat with a driver & the guide. The guide pointed out kingfishers, herons, egrets, a baby crocodile, a big monitor (iguana-like creature) & monkeys, including mothers with babies clinging on. The tour cost us 1200 rupees each & lasted for a couple of hours & was really interesting. Nice to cruise along the canal & through the mangroves - so peaceful. Thoroughly recommend this option. Avoid the hustlers & go direct to the Visitor Centre, but book 1st.
We took a boat ride on the Hamilton canal and the Muthurajawela mangroves. Lovely experience. Lots of birds.

We went for a boat trip for a couple of hours along the canal and marsh/lagoon. Saw iguanas, pelicans, a couple of monkeys and a baby crocodile. Others on a similar trip assured us that the animals are fed to keep them in certain areas for the tourists but the driver and guide on our trip seemed to do a good job spotting and pointing out the interesting sights. It was a nice trip, we were lucky with the weather.

I would really recommend taking a boat ride from Muthurajawela visitors center so you can explore the marsh. To get to the visitors center you must take a bus 15 kms out of town and wander along the edge a of a canal until you reach it. Foreigners pay about 1000 rupees for the boat ride which takes you along a canal and eventually to the large Negombo lagoon. Included in the price is a guide from the center who pointed out many birds, monkeys and even small crocodiles. In the lagoon we boated through many mangroves and saw local fisherman. For me this was the highlight of my visit to Negombo. The tour lasted just over 90 minutes

It is wonderful having someone to brief us first in the Musuem. Spending some time to collect some info in the Musuem, before going to the boat trip, proves very useful. The staff is very helpful. The boat trip is nice and comfortable. Better to avoid midday, too hot, easy to get sunburn. Seeing a lot of birds, a baby crocodile. If one loves the nature, one would love this boat trip.

We arranged the trip via an agent in Negombo Beach and the price was very reasonable. It proved to be a very pleasant trip along the canal and into the lagoon. Our knowledgeable guide pointed out interesting birds, monitor lizards, small crocodiles and local sights.Worth the money.
This is a very good place to go in a water boat. Can see lot of birds around the marsh area. good for a half day outing.

We had a small boat just for the two of us and had a great guide who could spot the wildlife from a long way off and was great at making sure we got what we wanted. A vast array of wildlife to see including a water monitor that the guide spotted where most would have missed it

Fantastic experience - traveling through the Dutch canals, swamps, lagoons and mangroves in and around Negombo. Our tour guide ‚ÄòJude‚Äô was great, very friendly and informative about all the different animals we spotted on the tour. I would highly recommend booking this tour if you are staying in Negombo

An interesting early morning excursion that will give the bird lover much to do. Do not forget to take your binoculars and camera. The guide is very knowledgeable about the local bird/wild life. Go before the area becomes commercialised; there is talk of /planning for a refuse collection operation that will surely spoil the marsh in years to come.

This marshland is part of the great Negombo Lagoon, which is an estuarine  lagoon which has water fed into it from small rivers and a canal. a narrow channel of water links it to the sea. The area is rich in swamp land and guided tours of the waterways are available to see the incredible array of bird and animal life that dwells in the water environment. We love to look at the lagoon in the early evening as bird fly home to roost. we regard it as one of Sri Lanka's very special places for wild bird life which is fascinating as it is so close to the noisy town life in Negombo, Katunayake and Seeduwa.

It was an early morning boat ride in the canal network of the Muthurajawela Marsh which gave so much opportunity to see the birds of this marshy environment. From Purple Coot (Swamp hen) to King Fishers, types of Herons, loads of migratory birds, Cormorants et. al were among the bird population. Spotted a baby crocodile, water monitor, some water snake, monkeys and crabs. The short journey across lagoon gave a glimpse of local fishing methods; one mentioned as "Jawakotu" and fishing on a "Theppama" something like a surfboard where a single stands on and fish. It was an enjoyable trip while learning a lot about the unique Eco system. 3 to 4 hours were well spent.
Think this place is the lagoon and you can do boat trips around it and feed the monkeys on monkey island nice cheap trip

Rise early to make the most of this boat trip which takes you down the Dutch canal and out into the lagoon. Ask for Amalkia. She grew up in the region and is an expert on all the plants and wild life.
This is a real joy of a trip. Our guide and her pilot were both incredibly sharp-eyed, and the sheer fact of being in a boat makes it easy to come really close to at least some birds and animals.

The river boat cruise on Mutharajawela Marsh is a pleasant and relaxing experience. I personally went on my boat ride at 10am, which is not the ideal time to spot wildlife and by then the mid day sun was at its hottest. We took the trip from a place just near the fish market and cost 3000rs for the 6 of us for an hour which proves that boat rides on the marsh dont have to be super expensive. However we did not see many species of bird, probably due to the time that we went but I was nevertheless disappointed. An interesting feature of the ride was that we saw a crab fisherman and he showed us some massive crabs that he caught. We then were able to hold them and have photos taken with then, although this came at extra expense as he expected a tip. Later though I found out that some people hold baby crocodiles when they go out on the marsh so I felt pretty jealous. A few days after this though Idecided to cycle to the Mutharajawela visitor centre around 25km away from negombo. I found out that boat rides cost 1600 rs per person from there. However these boat rides come with experienced tour guides who are good at spotting and identifying wildlife, while the whole overall experience is more pleasant. Each boat has around eight seats and so the boat rides are actually relaxing and peaceful rather than noisy and unwelcoming. The boat rides also go through the canals and then onto the lagoon, rather than just on the lagoon. I saw many species of birds and monitor lizards. The visitor centre however was hard to find and if you are in Negombo it might be less accessible as you will have to pay for a taxi to get there, otherwise you could just do as I did and cycle.Seven or eight in the morning is the perfect time to spot wildlife, such as pelicans, storks, bee eaters, kites, hawks, waders, etc. The visitor centre might be a more expensive than basic boat rides but is well worth it and is a MUST for those interested in wildlife. It is also cheaper than booking boat rides online or at a hotel. It is better to phone then in advance.Their phone number is 94 114 030 150

approximately 6,000 hectares inclusive of the Negombo lagoon. The daily high tide carries seawater from the ocean into the wetland. Constant mixing of these two waters over thousands of years, has led to a brackish, integrated coastal ecosystem that is biologically diverse and teeming with life. A diversity of mangroves and other types of flora including medicinal plants; numerous types of birds, butterflies and fish, some of which are endemic, are found in the Muthurajawela marshes

We were lucky to arrive when things were quiet and we had a whole boat to ourselves - our captain had excellent eyes for spotting birds, squirrels and monitors along the canal side and in the marshlands, and our guide was very knowledgeable.  Lots of birdlife to see - herons, cormorants, kingfishers and bee-eaters, pelicans and seabirds etc - as well as water monitors lazing along the bank.  A lovely leisurely way to spend a few hours and escape the hubub of the city.

Had almost a 2 hr boat ride covering the dutch canal, parts of the lagoon, monkey island (few monkeys reside on one of the islands and the tourists are encouraged to feed them) and also can get a glimpse of the flights landing and taking off at the airport. The lagoon/marshland is clean and has good variety of birds that one can observe. The boats men are polite, friendly and professional.

The Marsh is great for birds and other animals. We saw many water monitors, and a baby crocodile. The bird life is great, if your like watching birds, it‚Äôs a great place. The boat ride is also great, and our guide was very good at recognizing the birds we saw.

Our boat quietly nudged it's way gently into the mangrove after a 20 minute ride across the lagoon. Almost immediately, a ragged, unshaven troop of starved monkeys leapt out of trees and jumped onto the bow of the boat, scrapping between themselves on who got the bananas the skipper had just mischievously placed on the deck. It was enormous fun to watch and a photographer's dream. Recommended .

Did a boat ride in the afternoon. Magnificent mangroves,  verity of kingfishers and other kinds of birds. Maybe the people living around the Dutch canal should be more educated about the nature. Recommend anyone to do boat ride. Lot of people offering boat rides but if anyone need any assistance pls call Sanath on +94722903613. He also got rooms  for budget prices at Snow drop in Negombo.

I live near the Muthurajawela Marsh area and I must say that this place was a beauty some time ago. But now the place is little corrupted because of the pollution caused by people around this place. Still there are lots of things you can observe if you come to this place. If you are able to hire a boat and take a tour you would be able to see some rare birds in the morning time. There are some places where you can have a package deal where you get a tour guide too to get a better idea of the place. so... finally I can say that, this is not what it used to be but there are still some things that you can enjoy. cheers !
Went with expectation of bird watching, it was mid September, in two hours hardly saw any birds, saw couple of monitor lizards, natural beauty is very good.

Tropical Marsh land with extension to the saltwater lagoon. Lots of unique Flora and fauna. It's hard to find this kind of landscape anywhere in Sri Lanka. If you have some spare time in negombo ,try to make some time to make a visit

only a 20 minute taxi ride (approx 1200 rupees)from our hotel in negombo these marsh boat tours are a little gem for birdwatchers and nature lovers in general.Although i was on my own i was quickly shown to a boat with a driver and a guide for 1600 rupees and we were off cruising down the many waterways looking for wildlife ,after only a couple of minutes we saw a water monitor and shortly after kingfishers , monkeys and different raptors over the lagoon ,all in all a great way to fill a couple of hours ,many thanks to my guide and driver
Muthurajawela marsh is a major local and foreign tourist attraction in Negombo, specially for boat tours, and the area also supports local agriculture a lot.

The lagoon, canal and marshlands in Negombo are worth visiting under the guidance of a competent guide. We saw wildlife such kingfishers, warblers, monitors, and monkeys. We saw the different fishing methods used in the area. It was a lovely, relaxing activity into winding water fingers.

Me and my friends hired a boat and we ventured into the marsh lakes. Sometime into our journey, we were the only ones in the place and it was serene. Our boatman stopped at one of the marshes and we saw a few birds very close. We also saw a few big monitor lizards at a distance. The boat ride and the views are really unique and if you like backwaters, you must definitely take this one. Definitely recommend it.
Lovely to walk around and take a few pictures ‚Äì¬†a little quieter here than the rest of Negombo so worth checking out!

We had a lovely boat trip up the Colombo to Puttalam canal.   It was just four of us and our driver and host.  We spent a good couple of hours spotting all sorts of birds, water monitor and baby crocodiles. Our driver/guide was very good very knowledgeable, pointing out all the birds and wildlife along the way.
The marshes are a great attraction in Negombo although I feel that it is under great environmental stress. There are many mangrove forests dotted along

The place is not that touristic and we loved it. It is not that expenssive (we paid 1500 rupies each). We travelled with a motor boat for about 2 hours. The guide was realy nice. We saw plenty of unique birds and water monitor. A realy nice easy tour. Very recomended!

As a half day getaway from the chaos that is Colombo this is an excellent trip. If going here means a serious detour in your itinerary, I would not recommend. You will go with a boat through an old Dutch Channel and finally via open water into the magroves. Nature is beautiful and abundant birdlife, even though most birds we saw you will see elsewhere in Sri Lanka easily. The guide was extremely good at spotting and recognizing the specific birds. Do not go with expectations of seeing a lot of mammals.
Muthurajawela Marsh used to be a great bio- diversity spot for years. But recently Government of Sri Lanka decided to dump its capital's garbage to the marsh. It is very sad to know.

It was a bit difficult to find, a bit past Bopitiya, but once we arrived we had a great experience. The guides were very knowledgable and had amazing eyes to spot the birds and animals. We saw 3/4 species of kingfisher, water monitors and learnt about the fishing techniques of the locals which was really interesting. Well worth a visit. If you get the phone number of the visitor centre give it to your taxi driver and they are happy to give directions.

Methurajawela Visitor Centre is the start point for your boat tour of the Negombo Wetlands. It‚Äôs a low key operation but all the more pleasant for that. The guides are knowledgeable and eagle-eyed, spotting all the interesting fauna along the way. The boat is comfortable and the setting is quite delightful. First a short trip along the ‚ÄòDutch Canal‚Äô, then into the lagoon wetlands proper. The bird life is spectacular ‚Äì our highlights being kingfishers, parrots and a stunning purple heron. We also saw several monitors and jellyfish in the water, as well as a large group of young boys having a great time playing ball in the canal. This is a very pleasant excursion which is is well worth a couple of hours of your time. Avoid the heat of the day by having a fairly early start.

An early start to get the best out of this is essential.  Starting the boat ride at apprx 7:30 means the ealry morning birds were out but the canal and lagoon were quiet. We had such a peaceful and lovely time.

This fantastic birding experience is written up in Lonely Planet and we thought it was a famous trip. Our driver from the Gateway Hotel Seeduwa had to stop and ask directions multiple times. Perhaps the locals don't go there! We finally found the right place and set off on a private boat trip up the canal and into the marsh and spotting birds- egret, herons, kingfishers++, bee eaters, storks, red woodpecker, kites, barbets, parrots and flying fish- our guide caught several! We also saw a tiny crocodile and large water monitor! The canal and marsh were well protected and very comfortable to explore- worth the trouble finding it. I would recommend paying the driver to wait and take you back as there is not much passing traffic!

This is not a big thing or a big tour. It is just a local lookaround. You are just getting out from the port for a relatively small roundtrip. But on your way you can see the boats, floating ones and others destroyed by the tsunami, you can also see varanus, crabs, mangrove forest, monkeys living on islands, and people fishing for life. And it is also a built in program that somewhere in the shallow water you can jump out from the boat and fresh watermelon and pineapple will be served...

We visited the Muthurajawela visitors center and took a boat ride. Very comfortable ride with a guide. So please to see lots of birds specially Stalk bill king fisher, the largest king fisher in Sri Lanka. Traveled along the Hamilton canal and reached the Negambo lagoon. Seen lots of Mangrove plantations, lots of birds, aquatic fish and plants and flowers Worth the money..

When we had a day out from Negombo with Sri Lanka by Car (info@srilankabycar) our first port of call was Muthurajawela Marsh visitor centre where we bought tickets for a small boat and had a lazy two hours watching for (and finding) all sorts of wildlife, including crocodiles (and a baby croc - how lovely), monitor lizards, herons, egrets, kingfishers (blue and pied). Best to go in the early morning if you want to see a lot of birds and animals. We did - and it was a fabulous daybreak to elevenses trip.

It was a nice way to spend a few hours looking at the local birds and monitor lizards. The kids enjoyed it. Unfortunately the restaurant we were taken to on the river was full of flies but otherwise it was a 50 dollars well spent.

Part of a Negombo tour we arranged with the Tuk Tuk driver when we got there, for the boat ride only we paid 4,500 rupees. The boat driver wanted 6,000 rupees for 2adults 2 children, but you have to negotiate when there. We went during the afternoon, we never saw any water monitors, but a lot of different birds, the boat ride lasted for 2hrs. In between the boat stopped at a shallow area of the river where we got out and had coconut water, water melons and bananas. We also got to see some monkeys on monkey land.

This formed part of a half day trip from our hotel and I would say that in order to enjoy it as fully as possible, a good guide is essential. None of us knew what to expect but, invisible to us, our guide was able to quickly identify all manner of wildlife, quickly stopping the boat and allowing us to get as near as possible. I enjoy birdlife, and I was amazed at the variety of kingfishers, their size and ability to get reasonably close to get decent photos, even with a simple camera. This was an unmissable attraction, very much like the Balapitiya River in the Galle area.

We really enjoyed this trip. Just the two of us with the boatman. Travel slowly through the canal, take photos of the colourful birds: egrets, corcormant, bee eaters, heron, water monitors, water moccasins, mangroves, cashew nut, mango and avocado trees. Canal is 130 km long in total. So interesting and tranquil.

This was our first boat trip of three we've done this week and without doubt the best for seeing birds and other wild life. In addition to a boat driver there was a knowledgeable guide with good English, who pointed out 3 different types of heron, bee eaters, lots of beautiful kingfishers, some much larger than European ones. Lots of egrets, a few water monitor lizards and a baby crocodile.  Go early in the morning for the chance to see the most birds.

Do not miss this place if you come to Negombo. Even if you are in colombo you can reach this place within 30 - 45 min.Sincerely Bird lovers must visit. In Muthurajawela, I saw lot of monkeys, monitors and also a variety of mangroves.The downside is pollution.
It was a very pleasant trip.  Lots of jungle, lots of birds, a couple of water monitors, what more do you want?

We went for a leisurely, relaxing tour of the Muthurajawela canal and lagoon areas. Well worth it. Our young guide was very knowledgeable and pointed out the diverse birds and animal. We saw different kinds of beautiful colourful kingfishers, cormorants, egrets, terns, birds of prey, land and sea monitors, crocodiles. The mangroves were also fascinating with its unique ecosystem. Would definitely recommend this boat trip. Not expensive either.

This is a nice place for a bird watching boat ride and even for studying mangrove fauna and flora . The  visitor centre which organises the boat tour needs to be more organised with cleanliness. The place and the sorruonding is not at all appealing. The guides are knowledgable and helpful too but they are a bit too slow and not punctual. Make sure you start the birdwatching tour early. Book for 6.30 , then they will be ready by 7 am. You can see many birds including, stalk billed Kingfisher, common kingfisher,white throated kingfisher,cormorant,whiskered turn,striated heron,yellow bittern, little egret, large egret,cattle egret,purple heron. Water monitor and crocodile sightings is also common.
Muthurajawela Marsh is the famous attraction wetland of Negombo Lagoon. And is notable for its highly unique Ecosystem

Great Guides! They were very helpful, and spotted a ton of different birds, plus Monitors, and monkeys. Be prepared for the garbage though, there is a lot of it, and the Marsh and Lagoon are no exception. Just seems odd that little is done about it, sad really. We did see  4 or 5 different kingfishers, including the ultra rare sighting of one actually catching a fish, that was really awesome. A fun way to spend a couple of hours and learn about the flora and fauna.

Our B&B Janishi Residencies helped arranged this boat trip along with a tour of Negombo via Tuk Tuk. We were shown the boatyard and a wreck caused by the 2004 tsunami that still lies there despite the 12 year gap. The marsh starts out a little littered with plastic and such but clears up before you see the birds and water monitors. The ride is very relaxing and our guide even stopped near the shallow area where we could walk around bare foot in ankle deep waters of the marsh. We were served with ample king coconuts and watermelons during that break. The garbage at a small marsh island populated solely by monkeys was very disappointing to see. I do hope the government takes note and cleans it up or tourists wont be visiting this place that often.

Sri Lanka has some beautiful wildlife and a lot of it is within these mangroves "marsh". It's a shame some wildlife is being killed off or driven away. This place including the Dutch canal and the lagoon needs help and it's sad to see it in such an awful state. The crocodile "which I didn't see" need to be brought back. I know the fishermen need to make a living but I'm sure there's a way to segregate them. There also needs to be a big clean up operation put into place, I would volunteer my own time when I'm there to help clean up. The place should be as beautiful as the wildlife. Tourists will pay more to see beauty within beauty than beauty in garbage. OK that's my little rant over, hope more agree with me and share your thoughts. Let's fix this.

Booked the boat trip day before. Driver found the place easily for me. Go early before heat of day puts animals to sleep! Guide was very good in spotting different bird species, water monitor lizard, baby crocodile and monkeys. 90min boat trip cost 1800 rupees. Part of the money goes to help government to keep this conservation area going.
Frustrated. People started destroying this valuable place. Lovely green environment almost gone. Bus some abstractness still there.

Negombo's lagoon has a  huge variety of wild life. We got some great shots of the many species of crane that live in the shallow lagoon area. We saw several water monitors, visited a fish farm and the monkeys were a real treat wanting to get into the boat with us. Our guide provided bottled water, fresh pineapple and King coconut for light refreshments.  Our trip lasted around 2 hours starting from the beginning of the Dutch canal area. The only downside is the pollution in and around the mangroves. Great trip for any keen photographer.
Great place to visit. It's quiet, full of wildlife, and way off the beaten path. Worth a go to experience one of the biggest wetlands on the island.

This is a very nice activity to do in Negombo,you will observe the wildlife and you can see small houses along the canals how do people live there,very beautiful nature view.No need for any reservation just arrange it with your tour operator and he can take you there to the town where you will find many available boats taxi.

Picked up from our hotel as arranged and driven to wildlife centre just outside Negombo. We were a little later than I had hoped but the driver's knowledge, and that of the guide on the boat, made this a most enjoyable trip all in all. Leaving the centre, we took a relaxed journey down the canal and out into the vast Negombo lagoon. The guide was very keen to spot as much as he could for us and we saw quite a number of different birds and other creatures including a small crocodile and a number of various sized monitors. If you like spotting birds or other wildlife, I can recommend this trip.
Many times myself and my tour clients been there, done nice boat ride and seen lots of birds and water monitors. Don't miss that place.

Interesting boat trip! We enjoyed bird watching and sight seeing at the Hamilton Canal and Negombo Lagoon. We even spotted a baby crocodile! Wonderful wetland nature and professional tour guide during the trip. Recommended.

I visited Muthurajawela Visitor Centre with friends, it was a get-together with friends after a long time. We had a wonderful boat ride that took us through Hamilton Canal to Dandugama Oya (River) to Negombo Lagoon. The guide, Chaminda explained us about the mangroves and the wetland ecosystem. We saw many birds, monkeys and a saltwater crocodile. After the boat ride we had a nice lunch prepared at the small restaurant in Muthurajawela Visitor Centre. Highly recommend this place for nature lovers and they have life jackets so its safe to take your kids too. Remember to reserve the early morning boat ride to have a better experience.
A hidden place near Negombo. Had a wonderful boat ride through Muthurajawela Bird Sanctuary. Reasonable price. Highly recommended.

A beautiful sunset and a pleasant boating experience. Very few birds were spotted. However the few we saw were perched up on trees. Migratory birds were less. Saw a water lizard and storks feeding in the prawn farms...
Amazing large wetland with a diversity of species. Best early am or late afternoon. It is amazing that so very few people visit this.

Fab even if we hadn't seen any wildlife which of course we did in abundance the boat trip up the wetlands to the lagoon and back was great the deckchairs as seats on the boat were maybe slightly dodgy but "when in Rome" cheap and very cheerful guide had eyes in the back of his head brilliant
The Hamilton canal and the feeling of beeing among local people and Animalia,  housut,  originaali people liven√§.

The boat visit  starts from the Hamilton canal and ends up in Negombo lagoon. This is a good place for bird watching lovers. We saw several local and migratory birds ( cormorant, kingfisher,egret, lapwing,eagle...), a baby crocodile ,a monitor and also a variety of mangroves. Along the canal, the activities of the locals such as fishing can also be observed. The boat ride takes about 1.30-2 hours.I found it relaxing and peaceful.
Tour will take around 90 minutes. Better go in the morning or in the evening. Tripod going via Dutch cannel and goes up to lagoon. Charges for local is Rs:350 and for foreigners Rs: 1100

Loved meandering along the canal and lagoon whilst recovering from jet lag.  Helpful Mr Lucky guided us through and ensured the boat stopped long enough for us to take photos and discuss what we were seeing.  Amazing amount of bird life and a lovely way to spend a couple of hours one early morning.  Enjoy!

comfortable boat with a good guide, who can show a lot of birds, varan and small crocodiles. But if you are heading to the centre of Sri Lanka you can see exactly the same even more animals. just look around :-) if you stay in one place in Sri Lanka the whole time, than it would be a good experience for you.

Had a lovely boat trip around the marshland of Negombo. Good trip for those wanting to experience the village life around this area. Wish the area wasn't full of litter, mostly plastic and discarded polysterene boxes whice are harmful to marine life.

I took a boat tour and it was a great way to enjoy the wildlife.  It was reasonably priced and a relaxing way to sit back and enjoy.  The guide was very good at spotting the wildlife and driving the boat so that you could take pictures and enjoy the wildlife sightings.
A tad disappointing, 90 minutes of just chugging around in the boat. Expected to see more of the canals, but most of them are inaccessible.

This was a good starting point for us in Sri Lanka. it was an interesting journey to get there by tuk tuk (exciting!!) because we went though different areas, some very wealthy and the fish market. The boat trip was about an hour in a reasonably comfortable boat with a roof. Our guide spoke good English and was very informed about the animals and flora. Amazing to see monkeys just sitting in the mangrove! also water monitors and birds like bee-eaters and egrets (after a couple of weeks this all became commonplace however but still great!)

Muthurajawela is a marsh in Sri Lanka in the southern region of the Negombo lagoon, 30 km north of Colombo. It is the island's largest peat bog, and is notable for its unique and highly diverse ecosystem. "Muthurajawela" translates to "Swamp of Royal Treasure".
We took this boat ride from a man off the beach but he knew every bird and plant, very interesting . We saw monitor lizards and the coconut man making alcohol from the flower.
nice for fishing and exitic tour in negombo otherwise not many thing to do in negombo without drink and wathch sunset at negombo beach

Did a boat tour of the marsh on first day in SL.  Very good to see the local fishermen working and plenty of wildlife, particularly birds.  Beautiful views but all felt a little bit rushed, I would have preferred to spend a bit longer looking/watching. The disappointing aspect of the tour was the monkey's - they are wild monkey's but are fed biscuits by the tour guides so their guests can see them - not how I like to see my wildlife, makes it more like a zoo.

A boat ride in the marsh will both relax you and reward you with a wide variety of sights and sounds. Sounds include fisherman paddling their wooden boats, children laughing as they play in the river, water monitors rustling in the leaves (in the water they are quiet), and the wind blowing through the dense foliage.  Sights include many different colorful birds (kingfishers, bitterns, waterhen to name a few), fish, monkeys, and typical marsh plants as well as some less common plants (wood apple). Additionally you will get a glimpse of people's lives along the water. Do your best to find a boat with a shade cover and/or go early in the morning so that you can enjoy the relaxing and scenically rewarding boat ride without too much suffering from the heat.

but we should have gone earlier than 6 AM...the sun was already up....better to go at 5 perhaps. We did see monkeys, brown herons, hawks...and it was interesting watching the fisher men using different methods to make their catch. The sunrise made for lovely photos.
one of the best marsh in the world  . very good for birding. close to the airport and Colombo capital.

This is a nice excursion if you happen to be in Negombo, and have some time on your hands. The nature is varied and beutiful, from mangroves to marshland. We saw many different birds, and 3 iguanas and a water snake. We found these animals without help from our guide, who seemed more interested in enjoying the sun.

Beautiful boat trip on which you can see a lot of birds, varans and if you're lucky monkeys. When you go here by tuktuk, make sure your driver knows where he should take you. The place is quite hard to find. It's best to give him the phone number from the visitor centre. Then he is able to communicate with the people there.

First trip to don't recommend on Sri Lanka after 14 days. Realy nice nature polluted by people. Our guide could point on the birds only and didn't explain anything :( It was like rides on the river alone. For 1500 Rs. per person I expected more.

This is a dutch canal , the boat trips are starting from muthurajavila its about 20km away from the negombo beach, its really nice trip, the boat trip is lovely and the guide will explain about the site and different kinds of brids and other animals, trip is about 2 hours we enjoyed.
great half day out , hire a fishing boat if you can more fun ,and cheaper. when you go on the trip they take you to a arak making place where they climb coconut trees to fetch the arak very strong.
This marsh is a good Place to go for a boat ride and look for birds. If you have time its nice to spend some time here.
Very interesting and pleasant boat trip, very nice birds, amazing views. We took a lot of pictures and shot videos of birds and reptiles
A nice ride if you like nature and wildlife. Better to go early morning or in the evening. Definitely worth the experience.

There isn't a whole lot to do around Negombo but this day was one of the  more memorable. I rented a scooter and took the road from Negombo that runs along the coast to the Marsh.  It was about to pour rain when I arrived so the staff suggested I return after the storm had passed.  I headed out to get a bite of lunch and returned in an hour.  The ride along the coast  was lovey, the boat ride was very relaxing and my guide was very knowledgeable, able  to answer all of my questions and more.  I saw some wildlife, cormorants, egrets, heron, monitor lizards, but visited during the heat of the day.  I definitely recommend this and the drive along the coast road.

Beautiful area but spoiled by so much rubbish,plastic bottles ,poly boxes etc along the shoreline ,fishermen friendly and very helpful though they do need to do more also to enhance this fabulous area.

This was the last visit we made on a 3 week trip to Sri Lanka - a 2 hour boat trip though the tranquility and nature (birds, animals and vegetation) of an old Dutch canal and mangroves around the lagoon was an excellent way of spending the morning before the long flight back tothe UK. It is true that we did not see anything like as much life (in either number or variety) as we had earlier in the holiday in Yala and Bundala but this has the benefit of being within an hour of Colombo and Negombo. Not for those seeking high octane thrills (though you do get pretty close to some very large water monitors) but if you enjoy relaxing on a boat while coconut palms, banana trees, jasmine bushes to say nothing of giant lizards and a variery of birds slide slowly by then there are far worse ways of spending a couple of hours.  And your visit also serves to demonstrate the value of the wetlands as a tourist attraction (thus hopefully making it less likely that more and more of the area will be taken over by the expansion of Colombo City and its industries).

2 hours after landing in Negombo we were already at a boat in the Muthurajawela Marsh, and we were immediately fascinated by the beauty of nature in Sri Lanka.  you get to see some water monitors, a lot of birds and monkeys.
We went on a 2+ hour boat safari to find crocodiles and monkeys - we saw a lot of water birds and lovely scenery but no crocs or monkeys as it was a bit too windy.  Great trip out though!

Read about this in the Rough Guide.  There were some difficulties arranging a tuk tuk to get us to the small visitor centre but the early morning boat ride was very enjoyable.  We saw 3 different types of kingfisher, kites, herons and water monitor and had a pleasant trip through the mangrove islands and along a stretch of the old Dutch Canal.

We started the tour around 10am. We didn't prebook but a boat was ready when we got there so we didn't have to wait long. It's very cheap for locals Rs. 350 and for foreigners it's Rs. 1100. We started off on a canal where we saw a lot of kingfishers, koels, cormorants, etc and a lot of monitor lizards. The guide was well aware of the bird species and even knew some of the dutch names of the birds. Then we moved into the open lagoon where the sights are beautiful and saw a lot more birds, some herons, ducks, and on the nearby trees a group of monkeys.Some brahminy kites were flying above.  We rode along narrow corridors of mangroves and that was beautiful and great. Overall, we had a great tour. It isn't out of the ordinary species but it's great to know that a beautiful small bird sanctuary is present so close to Colombo. It is a great tour to do during a morning on a weekend, etc.

My friend and I took one of university lecturers on a bird watching trip here. We didn't see too many larger mammals or reptiles, except for several water monitors. But we did see quite a few birds: koels, cormorants, kingfishers, water hens, purple herons and ducks among others. The guides are quite knowledgeable and take you close to a sighting, so perfect photo opportunities! The boat ride last for about 2 hours and the trail is quite beautiful, serene and scenic! Best times for bird watching would be early morning or early evening. During the afternoon, its quite hot and chances of sighting birds are rather low. It's best to call and reserve a booking in advance. Would definitely recommend a visit here! It's close to the city and is quite affordable as well.

Bird lovers must visit, start your boat trip on a quiet canal, where you can spot for example stork-billed kingfishers, greater coucals or Asian koels (and other smaller stuff). Then the canal opens on a large lagoon, where you'll find the usual water-birds such as herons, egrets, bitterns, ducks, cormorants and others whose name I don't remember. I was amazed to see them so easily and so close. But for those trying to take pics, remember that a boat always moves, so it's sometimes frustrating because you see the birds but your auto focus is not enough to compensate..so tell the driver to stop the boat.... All the Staff were very friendly and knowledgeable. Great experience. Loved it.

We visited at around 10-11 AM since the boat came late. Our sightings were pathetic. We managed to see only a few birds. The children were let down since they came with a lot of hope to see good wildlife. Choose early morning or late afternoon. Its a good one time visit.

It was a nice trip to the marshes since we didn¬¥t have anything to do. There are loads of birds and some waran in the marshes. The area is relly beautiful. There are more Lagoons in Sri Lanka that you can visit. I would not particularly plan to go there if not because I am already there anyways.

You will have an amazing boat trip along the British & Dutch canals.  See the amazing bird life, water lilies & lizards as well as where jungle & marsh lands meet.  Friendly fishermen collecting crabs with their nets & locals doing their washing on the rocks.  You won't be disappointed.

This boat safari is well run, very affordable and our family of 6 enjoyed it, despite not seeing very much bird/wild life along the way.  We went early afternoon, so as other reviewers recommended, try for early morning times to see the best wildlife.  We enjoyed seeing young kids catching fish along the side of the canal using one finger wrapped in foil!  Also some village life visible along the way and kids swimming in the canal. Our guide was engaging, informative and spoke reasonable English.  It is difficult to find; our driver had never been there, although he lived in Negombo and it took a few wrong turns before we arrived.  There are signs, so watch carefully.  Boats have a tarp to keep out the sun, but suggest sunscreen for the reflection of the water and bottled water; its HOT!  There is a small gift shop onsite when my nephew bought a great hat; probably his favorite souvenir of the trip for around 3 dollars.  Bathrooms are acceptable (lots of bugs!) but bring your own paper!  Overall a fun, relaxing trip.  Defiantly recommended.
The boat safaris are wonderful. The guides are well knowledgeable about the area and the indigenous birds. Beautiful area with a lot of greenery and a nice lagoon.

column7: Emirate of Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
column11: Like the boat tour. I hate the smell of some areas. Can see lots of fishes baby croc swimming around. Some water snake. If you are lucky enough monkey.
Thoroughly enjoyed this trip, we saw monkeys, lots of different birds and monitor lizards.  The guide was very informative. Just a shame to see so much rubbish littering the side of the canal.

There was unnecessary hype about this marsh. We barely go to see a few birds and monitor lizards. The guide was very quite and inaudible and did not seem too interested. I've been on better marsh visits in Kerala. One can give this a miss!

It was a good trip where you can see a different type of birds if you do that early in the morning. And lot of mangroves and many island in the Negombo lagoon.It is adviceable to book a boat in advance to avoid delay to start the trip.
As there were four of us, we hired a boat from the many boatsmen by the bridge.  We saw monkeys on an island, water monitor, sea bream being bred, and best of all huge fruit bats. would recommend.

It was a little difficult to find, but we had their telephone number and got help from them to reach the place. The boat ride was nice, as it gave us the opportunity to see the canal and the laguna with plenty of birds and few more animals. Well worth the effort.

My advice to you, O Traveller: 1. Make sure you call the day before. We didn't know that they close at 6:00 pm, so we couldn't book ahead. We called at 7:00 in the morning and they asked us to come by 11:30, by which time it was hot, and too bright for good pictures. Also we didn't see any crocodiles, and only one monitor lizard. But there were a lot of birds and we didn't even need binoculars as our boatman expertly maneuvered us close enough to take pictures even with our phones. Go as early as you can. 2. They sell drinking water, but it's good to come prepared with your own water and a small snack if you haven't had breakfast as the boat ride is 2 hours and the sun can get hot. There is a canopy overhead so it's relatively comfortable. 3. if you have a residence visa (for foreign spouses) they are kind enough to charge you local fees so carry your passport or local ID. (most places also require my marriage certificate, but not here) The guide was very polite and friendly, and every time he pointed something out to us he would start by saying "excuse me" because he would interrupt the silence. although it's not THAT silent with the motor boat. 4. Lastly, and most importantly, the phone number and location on Google maps can be found when you search for "muthurajawela visitor centre" it also tells you whether they are open that day or not. It's about 20 km from Negombo  beach and took us about half an hour. Google maps ftw! It is government run, and in a wildlife protected area, so you don't need to worry that they'll cheat you. 5. Have fun!
Boat trip in the marshes. What you se probably depends on luck and the guide you get. We saw a number of birds and tiny baby crocodiles. Nice and peaceful.
Peaceful and interesting.  Small group and excellent guide.  Saw many birds and water monitors.  Life jackets provided!

A boat ride crossing the 17th century dutch canals with bird chirping, and bumping into an ocassional monitor lizard and crocodiles is how you would like to start your day, then Muthurajawela is the place for you. Although less than 20 kms from Negombo city centre, it took us nearly 45 minutes to reach as it is a bit difficult to locate the starting point for the boat tour. The boat tour is government organised and starts at around 7:30-8am. Earlier you reach, better the sightings as it gets hot after 9am. The tour costs LKR 1100 per person. you can call the centre on (094) 011 4030150 / Arunan to confirm a couple of days before your visit. The guide was knowledgeable about the local flora and fauna. www.radhical.com

Tip number 1 is to make a booking in advance although we were lucky to find a vacant boat and guide on the morning we went. Try and get the earliest possible slot for the day as most amount of birds/animals can be spotted at the early hours. Managed to see a decent amount/different varieties of birds. Some were migratory birds which are seen only during particular seasons. We also managed to see a crocodile baby and some monitor lizards. There are no eateries/restaurants nearby so please do carry some water and nibbles if you feel like snacking along the way. The guide was knowledgeable and was able to explain a fair bit about the birds and the plants. Recommended if you are keen on bird watching and photography.

A wonderful, little-known gem! About 40 min drive from Negombo. 1100 Rs per person for a 2 hour boat ride along the beautiful Dutch canal and into the lagoon. A nice knowledgeable guide was perfect for us birdwatchers. No mosquitoes and we didn't go fast enough to get cold. All in all, an excellent afternoon outing!
I went with an English couple the male being an avid bird watcher. I thought it was a worthwhile excursion. The guide was very knowledgeable and we saw quite a lot of bird and animal life.

It a lovely beautiful boat trip with lots of birds, water monitor to see. Beautiful scenic ride which is not at all commercial. The only downside is you have to be there by 7.30 a.m. and it is atleast 45 min away from Negombo. I would rate it as a Must do activity in Negombo.

My family really enjoyed this one and a half hour boat trip. It's really good value at 1000 RS per person. We saw 2 (tiny) baby crocodiles, loads of birds including kingfishers, bee eaters and Eagles. We went afternoon but if you go early morning, you are more likely to catch a sleepy reptile warming up in the sun. If you're a bird twitcher, it's a must! If you're not, it's still nice. Dutch canal and lagoon trip fun.

We had an enchanting boattrip in a beautiful surrounding. Only the two of us! No other people were around. We saw many kind of birds and different kind of land and water varans/monitors. It was absolutely interesting and very peaceful. We enjoyed the tour quite a lot.

We made the trip along the canals and lagoon at noon, and were lucky to spot a baby varan and a baby crocodile. As well as a lot of common and less common birds. The trip on the laguna is amazing. We had the whole boat to ourself!!!! William, Senta & little Ella.
We had the boat to ourselves with a guide that we negotiated with on the main road to the fish market. He was very knowledgeable re the bird life and nature of the marsh.
The sanctuary boat tour is a great value and an English speaking guide will point out the beautiful birds and with any luck baby crocodiles, water monitors and Bengal (land) monitors.

We had a Wonderful time at the marshes with a great boat trip from the conservation centre. The guide was very knowledgeable about all the birds and gave us time to photograph and watch all the animals and birds (which there were many!). Highly recommended!

Wow, what a great potential there is in the place! We enjoyed it every much and saw many rare birds. We were a bit disappointed by two things: 1) The boat driver can't speak more than very basic English. He does know the names of the animals, and he was a god spotter, but couldn't explain too much. 2) We booked for the earliest ride, at 7:30. We came from Colombo and had to wake up very early. When we arrived, we were told the guide/boat driver is sick, so we need to join another couple at 8:30. We were quite upset, because we gave our phone number to them, and they knew it from the night before. So... if you do similar thing, state it clearly that the should update you if there is any change. 8:40 arrived, and a phone call said that the couple will not join because they don't feel well or something. It was a bit annoying, but we enjoyed the trip itself.

First of all, I don't think Negombo is worth spending any time when you visit Sri Lanka, there are many better places to go! However, if you decide to stay here more than one night you should really arrange a boat tour to the lagoon! We made a reservation with the conservation office and had to pay only 1100 rupee per person. We expected this tour to be really crowded but we had a boat and guide for just the two of us. We have seen many birds (kingfisher, eagle etc.), monkeys, monitor lizzards (varans), a water snake and many more. It is actually quite far away from Negombo. Withna tuk tuk you should leave about an hour before the boattrip. Tuk tuk charged us 1500 rupee, including two hours waiting at the pier.
Lovely boat ride along the canal s to the marsh and lagoon.  Lots of iguanas and kingfishers.  Stopped off to find out how arak is made.

I found this place on trip advisor and I wanted to go. I was staying in Negombo and asked a few of those tuktuk drivers about it. Make sure your driver knows exactly where it is, because it is around 40 minutes away and kind of confusing to find. your driver will pass by the fresh food market, make sure you get some bananas and mangoes for the trip. I called in advance to book. I got there early at 8 am and i was the only one. after paying the very low fee, we left on one of the boats into the lagoon with the guide and my tuktuk driver. It was one of the most relaxing activities to do.  Saw a lot of wildlife such as water monitors, baby gators, and lots of birds. Highly recommended.

We have wonderfull bort safari in the evening we sowed lot of birds and fantastic sunset.. It was wonderfull thanks for our guide 'Shalu' he is the one arrange our tour best recommend  if you worn't to contact him 0094 77 8988989 and he has a website reasonable prices www.heritagelankatours.com
Loved the boat trip which included lunch in the middle of the lagoon. Saw trees full of fruit bats ,a water monitor much larger than I thought and plenty of egrets and other birds.

we had to call 2x to be able to get a boat trip on a Monday. the first cal they claimed they were fully booked, while when calling back half an hour later they still had place. And indeed, once we had arrived, they were not at all fully booked, rather the opposite. Only us on the boat trip, but we liked it a lot, in the shallow waters, seeing a lot of bird life.

Loved this boat trip along the canal. Lots of interesting birds including kingfishers and an eagle. Very hot in the sun especially in open boat. Operators did provide umbrellas but make sure you take your sunblock

Rented a boat from Jetwing Lagoon Hotel for a one hour ride.It was very quiet,beautiful and pristine.Saw many birds there also for the first time saw some monkeys living in the mangroves.There was nobody else there and was astonished as near Negombo this was the best possible spot to see.

We did the trip in the morning.  Definitely would be too hot later. Saw monitor lizards, egrets, kingfishers,  purple heron, eagles, terns, parakeets and a few butterflies. The guides were very helpful and spoke enough English to point out and name things but limited explanation. Thoroughly enjoyed the trip which was about half an hour from Negumbo and 1.5hrs on the boat. Cost 5, 000 rps for the two of us including tuk tuk and boat + a small tip.

We discussed our boat trip with the guide's son then phoned a few hours later to confirm. When we turned up with another person from our hotel they had forgotten about our booking and didn't apologise. They then tried to charge more than the agreed price and were quite rude when we objected. We had the tour and the guide was knowledgable but still quite surly. The lagoon was attractive and the boat was fine. The guide had previously agreed to take us back to our hotel but withdrew the offer. We chose this trip as it was recommended in the Lonely Planet Guide. It was a lot more expensive [7,000LKR in total]than other tours. I wouldn't recommend it.

Not a famous place, our driver got some difficulties to find here. Even their staff was curious how we knew the place. It's a peaceful place. Boat safari cost is reasonable, 1000LKR/p, for about 1.5h. We saw several kinds of birds (kingfisher, etc.), a small crocodile, a lizard etc. If you want to see more, better to go early morning or late afternoon.

Quiet and not too uncomfortable 'basic' boat rip down the Dutch Canal and into the south of the lagoon; good english-speaking guide.  Lots of birds and a water monitor, and local fishermen in the lagoon.  Trip by Tuk-Tuk from Negombo is quite eye-opening too, but it's half an hour away so the driver has to wait for you (agree a sensible price for that before you go!).  Hotels can arrange the trip for you, but you can save a thoud=sand rupees doing it yourself.  Busy at weekends apparently, with locals.
