With an early morning arrival from the states, we rested and did a late afternoon tour.  A morning tour would probably be optimal but regardless we had a good one.  Saw numerous species of birds, water monitor, snake.  Our young guide and boat driver were excellent and enthusiastic.  Got lots of good photos.  Call ahead for boat availability.

I didn't book a boat ride, but it seems better to book beforehand. We enjoyed watching birds, monitor lizards, monkeys and fishermen. The cost was 1100 rupees and the ride took nearly two hours. Personally it was nice, but too long and tiring. I slept quite a while on the boat!
It was a great informative trip. The little motor boats have a canvas roof which was definitely needed as we took our trip late morning. Great value for money.

Visited on our first day so we were very tired after a long flight, however what a wake up call, the place is alive with bird life, water monitors and glimpses of monkeys, a wonderful peaceful location which takes about two hours, take a camera and a hat.

We were there on the wrong time of day, around midday. We saw very few animals. Regardless of the animals, the sights weren't very impressive and the boat ride is a little expensive. Also very hard to find if you come by public transport!
could have spent the day on the boat so much to see and excellant photo oppatunitys nothing to dislike very varied visited a cinnamon and spice manufacture

Wasn't really expecting very much from this experience, but was pleasantly surprised.  We saw several species of birds at close quarters due to the skillfulness of the guide and boatman, we also saw a nice big water monitor, monkey's ... and the biggest highlight was the baby crocodile which my husband spotted.  The guide was super excited to see this as well...it's not something they see in this area often. Great in the morning ... don't leave it until the middle of the day, as it's far too hot!

Took a lovely morning cruise down the canal and into the Negombo Lagoon and the marsh. Our guide was knowledgable and a very good spotter. The boat driver was excellent at getting us as close as possible to everything we wanted to see. Saw many varieties of birds as well as both land and water Monitors.  Well worth 2,000 Rs each.
Bird watchers paradise.  A boat ride through the 100 kms stetch of the canal built by the dutch... You are definitely to see various species of birds

We took the boat ride afternoon, at 2 PM. Overall nice experience, seeing some birds, water monitors, a bit of the life on the canal side. The two hour tour is interesting but do not expect too much bird life. The boat is reasonably comfortable and the guide was knowledgeable and spoke good English.

Took a chance and booked on beach with Sarath. Great choice. Sarath and spotter were great and spotting and pointing out wildlife. We had boat to ourselves and the scenery in the lagoon was stunning Great to see the houses and way people lived along edge of canal.Stopped and saw the todi collector  Sarath happy topause and go back if you wanted photos of particular wildlife. Excellent value for money ¬£25 for 2 hours for both of us - and boat to ourselves unlike some of the others we saw. Loved it so much we reccommended to others in hotel who all also enjoyed it . We took his other trip in the opposite direction to the lagoon and mangrove swamps Fed the monkeys and saw many great things My friend does not swim and Sarath went out of his way to reassure her that the water was not deep and trying to avoid any bumpy bits. Highly recommend him Sarath Boat Tours 0776293652
Excellent for Nature lovers. Bird watchers paradise for you to get amazing. This is perfect place for your nature adventure holiday in Sri lanka

The marsh and lagoon make for a really interesting two hour visit. Both our guide and boatman were very knowledgeable about all the flora and fauna we saw - and very quick to spot everything of interest. If you start the visit reasonably early in the day there will be abundant active birdlife, water monitors etc to see, with many kingfishers, egrets, heron, and cormorants actively fishing.
Very interesting place to see.  Our guide Sarath was great. We had a very nice curry at rohan s place when we came back.

I had high hopes for this boat trip but was dissapointed with the disturbances along the way. We could hear noisy vehicles passing by right next to the marsh. However there were some good bird sightings & saw a baby crocodile as well. The serene experience was tarnished by the clear distractions of the busy roads. But this is a recommended site for any bird lover who comes to Negombo
A must do if you like wildlife. Great trip and the guides are very informative, really enjoyed it, there was nothing not to like?
Located by the Negombo lagoon and this will interest the eco tourists who wish to experience wildlife and strange plants specialized to the coastal areas. Worth a visit if you are in the vicinity.
There certainly are some birds to be seen and maybe even some animals to see but all in all it is just a boat trip so consider what you are ready to pay for it.

This is an interesting trip along the old Dutch canal and out into the  lagoon. You get to see a variety of bird and animal life, locals fishing and a wide variety of houses along the canal edge.Jumping fish about 100 mm in length lept in and out of the water- our guide caught one in his hand!The trip is supposed to take 3 hours- we were finished in a little over two but the sweltering heat had got the better of us so we did not complain. Rubbish is littered along the canal - a great photo of a small crocodile basking has a blue plastic bag next to it. One big negative- the boats need a canopy to offer some protection from the sun

We took a tuktuk from Negombo LKR1000 return), the drive in itself was very nice along the lagoon road and the dutch canal. At the reserve HQ you can take a boatride (LKR1100 pp) along the canal, through the south end of the lagoon and a bit into the reserve. Our timing was off -midday is the quietest time for birdviewing- but the trip was pleasant and the scenery worthwhile the trip. The tuktuk driver would wait for us and we were glad he did because we were the only tourists around. He joined us for the boatride, his first time and he liked it just as much as we did.

Taking the boat trip up the canal to the lagoon and exploring the wetlands was a most agreeable way of spending a couple of hours.  The guides from the centre did everything they could to maximise our enjoyment. Saw parakeets, kingfishers, ibis, herons, cormorants, monkeys and water monitors, as well as local boat fishermen.

It was very serene to just ride in the boat amongst the backwaters of this marsh... Had plenty of immigrating birds .. pity we couldnt spot a crocodile !! But it is one of the best attractions in negombo. Needs to be booked in advance
this is great for wild life in the wild. monkeys, crocks,monitors, bird life, fruit bats and many more this is a great trip and it doesnt cost the earth.

wot an adventue you can have in this marsh, up close n personal with mother nature (the wild life is marvelous). birds,crocs,monkeys,bats and many other creatures live freely here a must for nature lovers .

i am a frequent visitor to Sri Lanka but only recently found out about this trip. The location is not very easy to find - booking through a hotel might help, otherwise see my directions below taken from the visitor's guide. I did not have too much time to look at the visitor centre but we had reserved a boat leaving at 4 pm. My brief web-based research indicated first thing in the morning (the centre opens at 7.30 am) or last thing in the day (4 pm for a two hour tour - centre closes at 6 pm) is best. Life jackets provided although very, very gentle journey. My children enjoyed immensely. The trip starts by cruising along a Dutch built canal. This opens into the expanse of the Negombo lagoon. We saw extensive bird life including kingfishers, herons, egrets, kites, as well as a macaque monkey and water monitor. The two crew members - one tracker and the other driving - were very good and eagle-eyed. To enable close-up photography and to avoid disturbing the wildlife, the engine was shut down. I understand that these eco-tours were supported by the Dutch government in the late 90s until 2003. There is no further support. This is run by volunteers and attempting to show visitors the importance of conservation. They should ctainly be supported in their endeavours. Frankly, even if I we had seen no wildlife, it still would have provided a very pleasant way to spend half a day (including time to and from the centre). For reservations, (094)0114030150 or fax (094)0114887325. I also believe that they will soon have a Facebook site. Directions: Take highway from Colombo to Negombo, turn west (seaward) at the Tudella junction, 1 km north of Ja-Ela. Follow the Pamunugama Road. After 4km, just after passing the Bopitiya junction, a signboard on your left hand shows you the approach to the centre (approximately 500 m).
Seeing the crocodiles and going along the dutch canal was a great experience. beauty of Mangroves adds to it.

This was an interesting outing, in a boat along the Dutch canal and then on to the lagoon.  We saw a huge variety of birds including a rare kingfisher, water monitors, baby crocodile, monkeys. We were accompanied by a knowledgeable guide fromo the Muthurajawela project and the Jetwing naturalist from our hotel. They were both great at spotting birds and identifying them.

Arrange a trip here from your hotel.  We did that, and were dropped off at the visitor centre, which has display boards about what we were likely to see (not always helpful, many are only in Singha).  After a while, we embarked into the boat; we were the only visitor occupants, apart from guide and boatman. Both were very professional; the boatman was eagle-eyed, and stopped whenever he saw anything of interest - reptiles or birds; the guide very informative. We negociated the canal, and arrived at the mangrove swamps; utter serenity.  The highlight was perhaps seeing a baby crocodile.

Our passion not just riding bikes but cover some exclusive scenes. This Marsh has plenty of such places, opportunities but the weather should be perfect and also couple visits is a must to capture pictures of rare creatures. But most of the birds, sea creatures would be running away because of noise of boats and machines. Anyway nice visit in Negombo Marsh.

As a photographer, I had high hopes of seeing different species of birds and other animals. But this thing totally turned out to be a waste of expense. All I was able to sport was four species of birds and lots of monitors which you can see any where in Sri Lanka. This is a total waste of money and I would never waste my time here.
Plenty to see, lots of birds and monkeys etc, didn't see any crocodiles though. The hotel you leave from Jetwing Lagoon is amazing and the tour guides were very knowledgeable and friendly.
If you are traveling Negombo you should visit muthurajawela we can see lot of birds and animals its very close to negombo and through negombo lagoon you can visit muthrajawela

We did see king fishers, water lizards (can't remember their names!) and many other birds. Nice afternoon out but far too expensive for what it provided. We had to pay for kids who are only just 4 and 2 and half which I think was a rip off! We just sat on a baot and went up the canal and into the marsh. We just hope the money does go back into the conservation area.

I had a personal 1-1/2 hour tour along the canal and into Negombo lagoon and surrounding mangroves. It was naturally scenic but also very informative because of the guides knowledge of local history, flora and wildlife. If you're a bird watcher (I'm not) I'm sure 1-1/2 hours wouldn't be enough. We saw numerous wetland birds. The boatman was skilled at shutting down the engine and drifting up close to avoid disturbing the birds. I also got to see monkeys climbing through the trees at the water's edge. Directional signs to get there are lacking so make sure your driver knows where he's going. There is a very small info centre that wold definitely not be worth the trip on its own. I phoned ahead which was lucky. They had no regularly scheduled trips on Sunday since most staff are Christian. I called the day ahead and they easily arranged a guide for me at whatever time I wanted. I paid 1,100 LKR + tips for the guide and boatman.
I visited Muthurajawela two years ago and then in August 2012.  Unfortunately.  There wasn't as much birdlife to see this time around.

It took us some time to find someone who was willing to offer us a fair price. A lot of people ask ridiculous amounts like 9000 for 2 hours. Just say no thanks, untill you find someone who offers you a fair price. We left add 5,30 in the morning because we wanted to see as much wildlife as possible. It was really amazing, we saw the sunrise on the lagoon. The guide explained a lot about the way the locals fish in the lagoon standing on the ground in the water. And we got to see al the different fish that they caught. We saw some bats hanging in trees and flying. The guide brought a pinneapple to feed the monkeys, so a lot of monkeys came on our boat. We saw some big water lizzards aswell and lots of birds. It was a really good trip, and because we left so early we got back before it became really hot.

We arranged a boat trip on the Lagoon through our hotel and we were very pleasantly surprised to find ourselves on a bird life safari. Absolutely brilliant!! The guide from EcoTours and the resident naturalist at the Jetwing Beach, Arran Sivarajah, were both enthusiastic and knowledgeable making a truly memorable day, spotting 25 species in just 2 hours. Perhaps in order to see this many species you do need an early start like we did. A long lens and binoculars are recommended!!

It was a nice trip on the Dutch Channel and the Negombo Laoon, although it was very hot, I would suggest you start that trip in the early morning! But the guide was very nice and there were many bird, some alligators to see!

A nice half-day trip from Negombo and worth it. Go early-day or late-day to have a better chance of seeing wildlife.  I saw a bunch of herons and a few other critters. Just MAKE SURE you get good directions and instructions.  The bus forget to drop us off at the right place and then some locals pointed us in the wrong direction. For ease, you could get a tuk-tuk but it costs more than the entry fee and tour guide.  Well worth it for a nice birding trip near Negombo. Friendly staff and tour guides.

We expected a much better experience during the Muthurajawela Marsh but actully nothing much as we didn't see any birds or much of fauna. But it is large lagoon with lots of trees on the bank of lagoon.
I was very dissappointed as no proper boats, the guy cannot explin well and mostly nothing much to be seen.

I must strongly disagree with the previous reviewer. Muthurajawela Marsh is a fantastic place to visit & and offers a good introduction to Sri Lankan water-based wildlife. Whilst not as productive as an early morning or late afternoon, a visit during the heat of the day should still yield plenty of interest. I visited a few weeks ago in the late morning. Apart from a couple of other boats at the end of our visit we had the place to ourselves. This was a very peaceful way to spend a couple of hours. The boat has a motor but the driver cuts the engine when you get close to the animals & birds. There is a small visitor centre with some faded posters and a little background information on the marshes and similar habitat in Sri Lanka. The guides are volunteers as the Sri Lankan government withdrew funding for this enterprise several years ago. They deserve a huge amount of credit as they continue to run very informative trips on a shoestring budget. The guide on our trip had a real passion for birds and had better knowledge than any other guide I met during a 3 week stay in the country - including at the big national parks. Visitors can expect close views of a variety of water birds including cormorants, herons, egrets, lapwings, elegant wading birds (seasonal), terns, eagles & kingfishers amongst others. Large water monitor lizards patrol the canal and crocodiles inhabit the lagoon although they are quite shy due to persecution and are best seen in the evening. You will likely also see primates in the trees adjacent to the canal. To get here bargain hard with a tuk-tuk driver in Negombo. Take sun protection as there is no shade on the boat. A pair of pocket binoculars are useful too.
It was really hot & we had a good boat ride. But nothing much we seen otherthan some mangrovees and few normal birds. The guide gave us good brief about the wetland  & it was very tiring.

best to go with the hotel- we got lost before getting there on your own- it essentially starts out like canal boat trip through the village before you get out into a vast expanse of marsh lake birds galore + monkeys- a little safari experience ( all past pics lost on recent hard drive failure )

The Muthurajawela Marsh visitor centre is about 18 km south of Negombo. We visited at the end of our trip around Sri Lanka. After a day driving north from the tourist beach towns through the traffic of Colombo, it was lovely to have a final glimpse of some Sri Lankan wildlife. We saw no other tourists here and had a very peaceful boat ride. We had a small open boat for the three of us and the park guide, who provided complimentary umbrellas for shade.  First we cruised down the canal, stopping to view water monitors and birds on the way. Then we moved out across the marsh and saw macaques and more water birds. The guide was pleasant and knowledgeable. We visited during the afternoon and obviously would have seen much more if we had come early in the morning or in the evening but even so, it was a lovely experience. I think it is probably a good thing for tourists to visit and support the preservation of this lovely wetland. There were some good quality caps and such to purchase as souvenirs from the visitor centre.
